Project Preparation and Start-Up Support Facility (RRP VIE 45098) 
DEVELOPMENT COORDINATION 
 
A.  Major Development Partners: Strategic Foci and Key Activities 
 
1.  Official development assistance (ODA) commitments to Viet Nam have rapidly increased 
to support its social and economic development needs. During 2005–2010, $31 billion of ODA 
was approved for Viet Nam, and this figure is expected to rise to $32 million–$34 billion during 
2011–2015. 
 
2.  Increasing ODA commitments reflect development partners’ confidence in Viet Nam’s 
growth performance and ODA projects’ consistent achievement of development results. Despite 
this, a recent review of the portfolio performance of the 6 Bank Group, which provides 80% of 
ODA to Viet Nam, indicated that slow implementation is a persistent problem affecting ODA 
projects, with disbursement performance lagging far behind that of comparable countries in the 
region1. 
 
3.  Issues underlying slow project implementation and disbursement are (i) start-up delays 
as activities often commence only after loan effectiveness; (ii) differences in the procedures of 
development  partners  and  the  government  regarding  project  preparation,  implementation, 
procurement, and safeguards; (iii) a cumbersome and lengthy approval process; (iv) weak 
project management capacity; and (v) failure to ensure the timely provision of counterpart 
funding, which affects the quality of project documents and progress in implementation.  
 
B.  Institutional Arrangements and Processes for Development Coordination 
 
4.  These portfolio performance issues have been being discussed and addressed through 
the  6  Banks  Initiative  and  the  Aid  Effectiveness  Forum  (footnote  1).  The  6  Banks  Group 
addresses common portfolio performance issues through joint reviews, analytical studies, and 
policy  dialogue  to  harmonize  procedures  and  strengthen  country  systems.  The  Aid 
Effectiveness Forum facilitates dialogue between the government and development partners.  
 
5.  Achievements  recorded  to  date  are  (i)  common  guidelines  for  feasibility  studies  to 
facilitate and accelerate project preparation and (ii) the aligned reporting tool for use in both 
internal government reports and reports to development partners, which is intended to ease the 
reporting burden on project management units.  
 
6.  Ongoing activities include (i) harmonizing the development partners’ project concept 
paper and the government’s detailed project outline and (ii) strengthening country systems for 
procurement, social impact assessment, and environment impact assessment. Advance actions 
have been proposed to shorten start-up delays. Proposals have been made to reform the 
project  management  unit,  simplify  disbursement  procedures,  and  improve  government 
procedures for counterpart planning and provision and for adjusting ongoing projects. These 
proposals are being discussed with the government in the context of the ongoing revision of the 
legal framework governing ODA project management. 
   
                                                
1 Joint Portfolio Performance Review VII conducted in November 2011  with the 6 Banks:  Asian Development Bank, 
Agence  Française  de  Développement,  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency,  Export–Import  Bank  of the 
Republic of Korea, KfW Development Bank, and World Bank

C.  Recommendations 
 
7.  Addressing portfolio performance issues is a long-term process, as reforms often require 
changes in the legal framework that affect all public investment projects, not just ODA projects. 
Even  under  the  status  quo,  project  implementation  will  accelerate  significantly  if  start-up 
performance is improved by implementing advance actions and improving the quality of project 
documents. Under the current legal framework, financial resources are provided only after loan 
effectiveness, leaving a financial gap that Asian Development Bank assistance needs to fill.
